snippet: Stamford, Conn., used a grant to install light-emitting diodes on three sides of the building, which opened in 1987 to less-than-flattering reviews.
abstract: Stamford, Conn, train station, one of the busiest in the Northeast, adds over one thousand light-emitting diode strips to spruce up a design which commuters have long bemoaned as drab since opening in 1987; City Hall used $155,000 grant, allocated to bring art to public spaces, for the project; Stamford officials had requested grant recipients use light as a medium.
lead_paragraph: Stamford, Conn., used a grant to install light-emitting diodes on three sides of the building, which opened in 1987 to less-than-flattering reviews.

headline.seo: At Night in Stamford, Drab Train Station Dazzles
headline.main: At Sundown, Train Station Trades In Drab for Dazzling
headline.print_headline: At Sundown, Depot Goes From Drab To Dazzling
